content:
N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 9 ยง 5.8 - Executive order no. 8: establishing the new york state advisory commission on privatization and the new york state research council on privatization

State Regulations
WHEREAS, it is imperative that this State reduce the size
of its government, decrease the inordinately high price its taxpayers have been
required to bear for services delivered by government entities, and improve the
quality of those services; WHEREAS, by greater reliance on the private sector these
crucial goals can be furthered; WHEREAS, to improve the quality of government services and
lower their cost requires identifying those services that can be more
efficiently delivered by the private sector and those assets that can be more
productively owned by the private sector; WHEREAS, a comprehensive study should be conducted to
analyze the feasibility of the privatization of selected government assets and
services; and
WHEREAS, certain private citizens of the State have
informed me of their willingness to undertake without compensation such a
comprehensive study, and their expertise, judgment, and professional and
business acumen are invaluable assets; NOW, THEREFORE, I, GEORGE E. PATAKI, Governor of the State
of New York, by virtue of the authority vested in me by the Constitution and

Laws of the State of New York, do hereby establish the New York State Advisory

Commission on Privatization (the "Commission") and the New York State Research

Council on Privatization (the "Council"). The commission shall consist of the

Secretary to the Governor, the Counsel to the Governor, the Commissioner of the

Department of Economic Development, the Director of State Operations, the

Director of Regulatory Reform or their respective designees, and such other
members as the Governor shall appoint. The Governor shall appoint a chairperson
from among the members of the Commission. The Council shall consist of Ronald

Lauder, who shall be its chairperson, and such other members as shall be
appointed by the Governor. 1. The

Council shall: a. review existing feasibility
studies regarding privatization and any reports relating to privatization
efforts and experiences of national, state and local governments; b. analyze existing legal, regulatory and
contractual impediments to privatization; c. evaluate the advantages and disadvantages
associated with the various modes of privatization and conduct feasibility
studies, including cost-benefit analyses, to identify those assets and services
that if privatized would result in cost savings and improvements in the quality
of services; d. prepare and submit
to the Commission for its evaluation comprehensive reports on the results of
its research and presenting all practicable privatization options; and e. undertake such additional analyses and reviews, and prepare reports thereon, as
the Commission shall direct consistent with the purposes of this

Order. 2. The Commission
shall evaluate the reports submitted to it by the Council and make
recommendations to the Governor concerning those assets and services that would
more effectively and efficiently be owned or delivered by the private
sector. 3. The Commission and the

Council are hereby authorized to call upon any agency, department, office, division or public authority of this State to supply it with such data and
other information, personnel and assistance as they deem necessary to discharge
their responsibilities under this Order. Each agency, department, office, division and public authority of this State is hereby required to cooperate
with the Commission and the Council and to furnish to the Commission and the

Council such information, personnel and assistance as is necessary to
accomplish the purposes of this Order. The Attorney General, or his designee, shall act as legal counsel to the commission and the Council. Signed: George E. PatakiDated: May 12, 1995
[FN*] [Revoked by Executive Order No. 5 (Eliot Spitzer), infra.]
[Revoked by Executive Order No. 9 (David A. Paterson), infra.]
[Revoked by Executive Order No. 2 (Andrew M. Cuomo), infra.]
